I was in a similar situation when I was in 61A, and ended up just barely declaring. Considering you're worried about declaring, I would go so far to recommend just taking 61B alone. It's one of the most fundamental CS courses you will take at Berkeley, and beyond the letter grade you really want to make sure you understand the material, so having more time to digest concepts by taking a lighter workload would be in your benefit. It's also no easy class--there are homeworks, LONG projects, and weekly labs.

A lot of students are focused on finishing as many requirements as they can, but there really is no rush. Focusing on meeting the GPA cap should be your top priority. You can hold off on 16B until you declare if you're not that interested in the subject because 16B is a quite a heavy workload as well. There will be plenty of time to take all the class you want to (unless you're a double major) coming from my experience as a senior. That being said, if you don't have summer plans, would recommend looking into CS 70 over the summer as an alternative option (that's what I did).

You should look at the state of your understanding. Why are you thinking of taking 70 before completing 16B? Is it because you are finding the math and problem solving in 16A a breeze? (i.e. you take one look at the HW and you can systematically figure out what to do without spending any time at all, despite never having seen this stuff before?) Remember, the circuits module in 16A can be viewed as nothing more than a simple playground for basic problem solving skills. (That is why the use of physical intuition is discouraged there --- in almost all cases, this leads to "bad form" and underdeveloped mathematical intuition.) If it's all easy for you, then certainly go ahead. If fear does not interfere and you can systematically and confidently invoke the definitions and go through derivations and tackle unknown problems, then you might already possess the sophomore mathematical maturity that is the prerequisite for 70. In that case, you might as well take 16B together with 70 (you can just sit in the same lecture hall --- they happen to be one after the other). If not, then you almost certainly need to take 16B before taking 70 (which you can do in the summer if you want). 16B will keep ramping up your maturity and help you develop the thinking skills required to be able to tackle 70. (This is also the case if you have any interest in machine learning --- after all, 16A and 16B are the core lower-division machine learning courses. That's what the material is largely about even though the underlying skills are broadly applicable to everything.) 

Remember, the EECS lower-division courses are designed in a way for a reason. They are meant to be taken two at a time, and to constantly challenge you while helping you grow. Yes, they can take a lot of your time. But they reward you for it. So it really makes no sense to skip ahead in the 16A, 16B, 70 trilogy if you're not ready. That sounds contrary to your goals and it serves no purpose. 

Students consistently underestimate the deeper thinking-skills dimension of courses and overestimate the surface-level subject matter. Your education is building a solid foundation for a career spanning decades --- nothing is really about the surface-level details.

I am struggling on deciding whether to take CS61B + CS70 together next semester or CS61B + EE16B. I would then take CS70 next year in the fall and then declare (hopefully).  

I need to do well in both classes in order to declare and it's looking like i'll end up with a B/B+ in CS 61A and the GPA cap is 3.3 in CS70, CS61B and CS61A.

Do you think it would be better to take them together and possibly declare sooner or take them separately and be able to focus on getting the grade in each class. 

I've heard multiple things from different counselors but I want the students perspective. Thank you!!!
